#Text=Rugby football
#Text=Rugby football is a game named for the school in the English town of Rugby .
#Text=There are two main versions : rugby union with 15 players a side ( with a 7-a-side variant ) , and rugby league with 13 players a side ( with 7-a-side and 9-a-side variants ) .
#Text=Rugby union is played in many countries , whereas rugby league is little played beyond Australia , Papua New Guinea , the south of France and the north of England .
#Text=History
#Text=Many towns in Britain had traditional ball games , but the rules were entirely local and unwritten , and games were mob affairs akin to pitched battles .
#Text=In the early 19th century , it still was n't agreed whether you were meant to kick or throw the ball .
#Text=The legend goes that during a match at Rugby School in 1823 , young William Webb Ellis opted to pick up the ball and run with it .
#Text=Whether or not he did so , it was that school that first wrote rules for the game we now call rugby .

#Text=Most clubs preferred the non-handling game and founded The Football Association ( hence " Association football " , or " soccer " in short ) in 1863 , but 21 clubs led by Blackheath split away , and formed the Rugby Football Union ( RFU ) in 1871 .

column1: #Text=The schism with soccer was made permanent by accident , when changes in the making of balls caused the rugby ball to become elongated .
#Text=This was crucial : you can kick a spherical ball with accuracy over distance , at close quarters dribble it round your opponents , and head it , flick it and all sorts of tricks .
#Text=You ca n't do so with an ellipsoid ball as the kicker 's contact is too variable , the bounce is unpredictable and the ball bobbles not rolls ; it 's better to carry and pass it .
#Text=It 's also more snug to hold than a spherical ball .
#Text=The RFU required players to be amateurs , which was alright for the nobility and a growing middle class with money and leisure time .
#Text=But working-class men lost wages if they took time off for games and training , and clubs from the industrial north of England sought to refund them with " broken time payments " .
#Text=The RFU would n't accept this so in 1895 those northern clubs broke away , forming the Rugby Football League ( RFL ) .
#Text=This second schism was very bitter : the RFU banned not only payment but any taint of association with rugby league , even in an unpaid or non-playing capacity .
#Text=It took human rights legislation in the 1990s and a string of lawsuits to bring the RFU to its senses .
#Text=Both games are now professional at their higher levels , and there is some cross-over of players , but the geographical distribution of fans for both codes still bears the scars of the split ;
#Text=in England , support for rugby union is still largely concentrated in the south , while support for rugby league is still largely concentrated in the north .
#Text=Britain exported rugby to its colonies , who swiftly learned to beat the mother country at her own game - New Zealand became pre-eminent , and remains so over a century later .
#Text=Rugby also became popular in France , Argentina and Italy , and to a lesser extent elsewhere .
#Text=Large countries where it never took hold include India , the United States , Russia and China ( except Hong Kong ) .
#Text=In the 21st century women 's rugby union has greatly developed .
#Text=Going to a match
#Text=The top matches are the internationals .
#Text=These sell out weeks in advance - check the host nation union 's official website for ticket sales , and be wary of online scalpers .
#Text=( Plane and hotel prices will also be hiked . )
#Text=These matches are usually on TV , and watched in pubs on widescreen .

#Text=At the level below , of professional clubs , you should have little difficulty getting tickets , or getting into the stadium on the day , yet you 'll see top-ranked players doing their stuff with skill and verve .
#Text=Games lower down the pyramid are thinly attended , the skill and athleticism are not so fine , but the impact and intensity are all there .
#Text=See the Wikivoyage travel pages for the relevant cities for practicalities .
#Text=You will always be welcome .
#Text=Rugby union rival fans mingle amicably inside and outside the stadium , and abhor the hostilities and hooliganism that too often mar soccer games .
#Text=Keep the violence on the pitch , where it 's controlled by the rules and the referee 's whistle . "

#Text= The referee has two assistants or " touch judges " on the sidelines , and big games have a fourth video referee or TMO : " Television Match Official " .

#Text=The game is played with 15 a side , players 1 to 8 being  forwards " , 9 to 15 being " backs " ie defensive , and up to eight substitutes , 16 to 23 .

column1: #Text=They play on a pitch 100 m long by 70 m wide with an H-shaped goal at each end .
#Text=Players seek to advance the ball across any part of their opponents ' goal line ( not just the H ) to score a try , worth 5 points .
#Text=Players may run with or kick the ball in any direction , but may only pass the ball backwards or horizontally .
#Text=A player carrying the ball may be tackled , no small matter if that player weighs 120 kilo and is running hard .
#Text=The tackled player must release the ball , whereupon there is a struggle to regain it , usually in the form of a " ruck " .
#Text=There are two halves of 40 min , with teams switching ends ; there is no added time because the referee stops the clock at interruptions to play .
#Text=However play does n't stop on the 40 min , but whenever the ball next goes dead :
#Text=there are thrilling examples of teams keeping play alive in " red-clock " time to snatch a victory .
#Text=To score a try , the ball must be securely grounded in the opponent 's " in-goal area " - dropping it does n't count , and the defenders may contrive to get under the ball and hold it up .
#Text=The try-scoring team is also awarded a conversion , earning two more points if it 's kicked over the crossbar of the H-shaped goal .

#Text=These names came about because before 1886 the try did n't score points ; it just provided an opportunity to " try " to kick a goal unimpeded by the opponents , and a successful kick would " convert " the try into a goal .
#Text=The kick is taken in line from where the ball was grounded , so try-scorers attempt to go central to give their kicker a better angle .
#Text=Players may also drop kick the ball over the goal crossbar during open play , for a drop goal worth 3 points .
#Text=It 's a tricky manoeuvre and not often attempted .
#Text=Most scores come from penalty kicks awarded for serious infringements .
#Text=Teams have a choice of how to play from a penalty , but often opt for a place kick at goal , worth 3 points if it clears the crossbar .
#Text=Hustling your opponents into mistakes that incur a penalty is an important part of attack .
#Text=There are several set plays .
#Text=A lineout is awarded if the ball goes over the sidelines " into touch " .
#Text=The lines themselves are in touch , so a ball or player carrying the ball and setting foot on the line is out of play ( likewise a ball grounded on the goal line itself is a try . )
#Text=Normally the other side then has a throw-in to the two lines of opposing players , but if the ball has gone out from a penalty kick , that side gets the throw-in .
#Text=This is a common attacking ploy : you kick for touch close to the goal line , hoping to win the line-out and charge over for a try .
#Text=A scrum is awarded for a minor infringement : the forwards crouch into a 3-4-1 set , while the " scrum-half " feeds the ball in .
#Text=The ball may not be handled within the scrum .
#Text=Messy , collapsing scrums are the game 's least attractive feature , and carry risk of injury .
#Text=What counts as a minor or major infringement often depends on the game situation , eg did it thwart a promising attack , was it deliberate or repeated offending , was it physically dangerous ?
#Text=Common offences usually deemed minor are forward passes , knock-on ( i.e. ball forward from hand to ground ) , and tackled player not releasing the ball .
#Text=It 's usually a penalty for collapsing a scrum or being offside , ie competing for the ball from in front of it .
#Text=For an offence that thwarts a probable try the referee may award a penalty try , 5 instant points and a conversion kick for two more .
#Text=For serious misconduct such as a dangerous tackle , a player could be sent off for 10 minutes ( " yellow card " ) , or for the rest of the game ( " red card " ) .
#Text=In a game that 's all about weight and numbers , that hands a big advantage to the other team .
#Text=Referees are martinets from a bygone era , and visible dissent from their decisions is punished more rigorously than in other sports .
#Text=Rugby sevens is a variant of rugby union with only 7 players , but using the same sized field , so play is fast and open , a real test of fitness .
#Text=A few rules and set-plays are adapted , eg scrums are of three players , and penalty goals and conversions are from drop kicks not place kicks .
#Text=The game is two halves of 7 or 10 minutes ; this lends itself to tournaments with all the games played over a single weekend , or sometimes even a single day .
#Text=Drop goals and penalty goals are extremely rare in rugby sevens , and the vast majority of points are scored from tries .
